segments.title: Supervised Learning
segments.text: Supervised learning is a type of machine learning that involves using labeled datasets to train algorithms to classify data or predict outcomes accurately. It includes two main types: classification and regression.

segments.title: Unsupervised Learning
segments.text: Unsupervised learning is a type of machine learning that deals with input data without labeled responses. The goal is to discover intrinsic structures in the data, such as grouping or clustering of data points.

segments.title: Classification in Supervised Learning
segments.text: A supervised learning task known as classification involves predicting the class or category of an object or sample based on its features. Classification algorithms are used when the output is a category, such as 'spam' or 'not spam', and 'fraudulent' or 'not fraudulent'. The algorithm learns from the training data and uses that knowledge to classify new, unseen data. An example of a classification task is Email Spam Detection, which involves classifying emails as spam or not.

segments.title: k-Nearest Neighbours (k-NN)
segments.text: k-Nearest Neighbours (k-NN) is a classification algorithm used for classifying objects based on the closest training examples in the feature space. It operates by finding the k training examples nearest to the new data point and assigning the most common class among those k examples to the new data.

segments.question: What is the k-Nearest Neighbours (k-NN) algorithm?
segments.answer: k-NN is a classification algorithm (1 point) that classifies objects based on the closest training examples in the feature space (1 point). It assigns the class by looking at the most common class among the k nearest examples to the new data point (1 point).

segments.title: Naive Bayes
segments.text: Naive Bayes is a classification algorithm that assumes independence among predictors. It calculates the probability of each category based on the features and assigns the category with the highest probability to the new data point. Despite its simplicity, Naive Bayes can be particularly effective in certain applications.
